categories.title: Communication & Presentation
categories.description: Master the art of clear, confident communication during interviews

tips.title: Maintain appropriate eye contact
tips.description: Make eye contact 60-70% of the time. Look at the interviewer when they're speaking and when you're making key points.
tips.example: When answering 'Tell me about yourself,' look at the interviewer while highlighting your key achievements.

tips.title: Speak clearly and at a moderate pace
tips.description: Speak slowly enough to be understood, but not so slow that you seem uncertain. Pause between thoughts.
tips.example: Instead of rushing through your experience, take brief pauses: 'I led a team of five developers... [pause] ... and we delivered the project two weeks ahead of schedule.'

tips.title: Practice active listening
tips.description: Show you're engaged by nodding, asking clarifying questions, and referencing what the interviewer said.
tips.example: You mentioned earlier that teamwork is crucial here. In my last role, I collaborated closely with the design team to...

tips.title: Don't overuse filler words
tips.description: Minimize 'um,' 'uh,' 'like,' and 'you know.' It's better to pause briefly than to fill silence with these words.
tips.example: Instead of: 'So, um, like, I worked on, uh, several projects...' Say: 'I worked on several key projects... [brief pause] ...including a customer portal redesign.'

tips.title: Don't interrupt the interviewer
tips.description: Let them finish their questions completely. If you need clarification, wait for them to finish, then ask.
tips.example: Wait for the complete question, then respond: 'That's a great question about leadership. Could you clarify what type of leadership scenario you'd like me to focus on?'

categories.title: Technical Interview Excellence
categories.description: Navigate technical questions and coding challenges with confidence

tips.title: Think out loud during problem-solving
tips.description: Verbalize your thought process when tackling technical problems. This shows your problem-solving approach.
tips.example: 'I'm thinking about this as a sorting problem... Let me consider the time complexity... A merge sort would be O(n log n)...'

tips.title: Ask clarifying questions for technical problems
tips.description: Before diving into a solution, make sure you understand the requirements, constraints, and expected inputs/outputs.
tips.example: 'Before I start coding, can I clarify: What's the expected size of the input? Are there any memory constraints I should consider?'

tips.title: Discuss trade-offs in your solutions
tips.description: Show you understand different approaches by explaining why you chose your solution and what alternatives exist.
tips.example: 'I'm choosing a hash map here for O(1) lookup time, which uses more memory but gives us better performance than a linear search.'

tips.title: Don't jump straight into coding
tips.description: Take time to understand the problem, discuss your approach, and get alignment before writing code.
tips.example: Instead of immediately coding, say: 'Let me make sure I understand this correctly...' and outline your approach first.

tips.title: Don't give up if you're stuck
tips.description: If you're struggling, explain where you're stuck and ask for hints. Show resilience and problem-solving persistence.
tips.example: 'I'm having trouble optimizing this further. Could you give me a hint about the data structure that might work better here?'

categories.title: Behavioral Questions & STAR Method
categories.description: Master behavioral interviews using proven storytelling frameworks

tips.title: Use the STAR method for behavioral questions
tips.description: Structure answers with Situation, Task, Action, Result. This provides clear, complete responses to behavioral questions.
tips.example: Situation: 'Our team was behind on a critical project...' Task: 'I needed to get us back on track...' Action: 'I organized daily standups...' Result: 'We delivered on time with 98% quality score.'

tips.title: Prepare 5-7 detailed examples
tips.description: Have specific stories ready that demonstrate leadership, problem-solving, teamwork, conflict resolution, and achievement.
tips.example: Prepare stories for: overcoming a challenge, leading a team, dealing with conflict, learning from failure, achieving a goal, working under pressure.

tips.title: Quantify your results when possible
tips.description: Use specific numbers, percentages, timeframes to make your impact clear and memorable.
tips.example: 'I reduced processing time by 40%, saved the company $50K annually, and improved customer satisfaction scores from 3.2 to 4.7.'

tips.title: Don't give vague or generic answers
tips.description: Avoid answers like 'I'm a team player' without specific examples. Always back up claims with concrete stories.
tips.example: Instead of 'I'm good at problem-solving,' say: 'When our main server crashed during peak hours, I quickly identified the issue, implemented a workaround, and had us back online in 15 minutes.'

tips.title: Don't focus excessively on problems or blame others
tips.description: Even when discussing challenges, focus on your actions and learnings rather than dwelling on problems or blaming teammates.
tips.example: Instead of 'My manager was terrible and the project was a disaster,' say: 'I learned to adapt my communication style and found ways to keep the project moving forward despite challenges.'

categories.title: Body Language & Presence
categories.description: Project confidence and professionalism through your physical presence

tips.title: Maintain confident, open posture
tips.description: Sit up straight, keep shoulders back, and avoid crossing arms. Lean slightly forward to show engagement.
tips.example: Sit with both feet on the floor, hands visible on the table or in your lap, maintaining an open chest position throughout the interview.

tips.title: Offer a firm, confident handshake
tips.description: Make eye contact, smile, and give a firm (not crushing) handshake when greeting interviewers.
tips.example: Stand up, make eye contact, smile genuinely, and say 'It's great to meet you' with a confident handshake that matches their grip strength.

tips.title: Use purposeful hand gestures
tips.description: Natural hand movements can emphasize points, but keep gestures controlled and purposeful.
tips.example: When explaining a process, use your hands to show progression or size. When making three points, count them on your fingers.

tips.title: Don't fidget or display nervous habits
tips.description: Avoid pen clicking, leg bouncing, hair touching, or other repetitive movements that can be distracting.
tips.example: Keep your hands occupied by holding a portfolio or resting them calmly. If you tend to fidget, practice sitting still during mock interviews.

tips.title: Don't adopt closed or defensive postures
tips.description: Avoid crossing arms, leaning away, or turning your body away from the interviewer. These signal discomfort or disengagement.
tips.example: Instead of crossing arms when thinking, place one hand on your chin or keep both hands visible and relaxed.

categories.title: Interview Preparation & Research
categories.description: Set yourself up for success with thorough preparation strategies

tips.title: Research the company thoroughly
tips.description: Study the company's mission, recent news, products, culture, and the specific team you'd be joining.
tips.example: Read their latest blog posts, annual reports, recent press releases, and employee reviews on Glassdoor. Follow their LinkedIn and social media.

tips.title: Prepare thoughtful questions to ask
tips.description: Have 5-7 specific questions ready about the role, team, company culture, growth opportunities, and challenges.
tips.example: 'What does success look like in this role after the first 90 days?' 'What are the biggest technical challenges the team is facing?' 'How does the company support professional development?'

tips.title: Practice answers to common questions
tips.description: Rehearse responses to standard questions, but don't memorize scripts. Practice until your answers flow naturally.
tips.example: Practice: 'Tell me about yourself,' 'Why do you want this job?' 'What's your greatest weakness?' 'Where do you see yourself in 5 years?'

tips.title: Don't wing it without preparation
tips.description: Even if you're highly qualified, lack of preparation shows and can cost you the opportunity.
tips.example: Don't assume you can 'figure it out' during the interview. Spend at least 2-3 hours researching and preparing beforehand.

tips.title: Don't ask generic or easily googled questions
tips.description: Avoid questions about basic company info that's readily available online. This shows you didn't do your homework.
tips.example: Don't ask 'What does your company do?' or 'How big is your team?' Instead, ask about specific challenges or growth plans.
